data.text: Lagarde: Together with the substantial monetary policy stimulus already in place, these measures will support liquidity and funding conditions for households, businesses and banks and will help to preserve the smooth provision of credit to the real economy
Lagarde: We decided on a comprehensive package of monetary policy measures
Lagarde: In line with our mandate, the Governing Council is determined to support households and firms in the face of the current economic disruptions and heightened uncertainty
Lagarde: We welcome the decisions taken by the ECB’s Supervisory Board, which are detailed in a separate press release published earlier today.

Lagarde: We strongly supports the commitment of euro area governments and the European Institutions to joint and coordinated policy action in response to the repercussions of the spread of the coronavirus
Lagarde: An ambitious and coordinated fiscal policy response is required to support businesses and workers at risk

Lagarde: Governments and all other policy institutions are called upon to take timely and targeted actions to address the public health challenge of containing the spread of the coronavirus and mitigate its economic impact
Lagarde: …it will slow down production as a result of disrupted supply chains and reduce domestic and foreign demand, especially through the adverse impact of the necessary containment measures (2/2)
Lagarde: Even if this shock is ultimately temporary in nature, it will have a significant impact on economic activity… (1/2)

Lagarde: Since our last Governing Council meeting in late January, the spread of the coronavirus (COVID-19) has been a major shock to the growth prospects of the global and euro area economies and has heightened market volatility

If you’re a woman studying, or about to study, for a Master’s with a major in economics or with a specialisation, take a look at our Women in Economics scholarship. Applications open soon https://t.co/CpOG62QuHp (4/4)

We know there’s more work to do at the ECB and we’re continuing to work to lower barriers that women face here. We also want to reach talented female economics students and to encourage women to apply for roles in central banking (3/4)

Our research found the promotion gap significantly reduced after we adopted diversity policies across 4 areas:
- attracting female candidates
- enhancing the internal pipeline of female candidates
- enabling a sustainable work-life balance 
- holding ourselves accountable (2/4)

[THREAD] An equal world is an enabled world. #InternationalWomensDay 

Central banking and economics are fields where women are under-represented. We’re committed to providing a level playing field for men and women alike here at the ECB (1/4) https://t.co/NP79Gh2yk4

Are you researching diversity and inclusion in economics and finance? Apply by 30 April to present your work at the @federalreserve’s conference organised together with @bankofengland, @bankofcanada and the @ecb https://t.co/B36kTQFGFz

What are the risks emerging from climate change? Why is international cooperation key to ensure a smooth transition towards a low-carbon economy? Tune into #TheECBPodcast with our host @MichaelSteen and expert guest Fatima Pires to find out https://t.co/9M91nvkCjG https://t.co/crAndLyWxi
Read our new report on financial integration and structure to learn more https://t.co/AdTaPHaxQf [6/6]

Further development of equity markets could help decarbonise EU economies. EU countries where companies finance themselves mainly through equity rather than bank credit or other forms of debt have shrunk their carbon footprints more in recent decades than other countries [5/6]

Private equity markets – where non-listed shares are traded – should become a more dynamic source of risk capital, which would give rise to better growth opportunities for young and innovative companies [4/6]

The structure of the euro area financial system shows movement from a dominance of banks towards a more balanced composition in which other financial intermediaries such as investment funds or financial corporations engaged in lending play a greater role [3/6]

Financial integration developments over the last two years have been mixed. There is still some way to go to a single market for financial services. Euro area citizens, firms and governments would benefit from broader and deeper capital markets [2/6]

[THREAD] Our report on financial integration and structure in the euro area discusses key structural developments and financial sector policies. Read on for key findings https://t.co/utDczzoX0x [1/6] https://t.co/VGEwqGFa7Y

Why isn’t the ECB buying more green bonds? How does climate change affect financial stability? @MichaelSteen discusses these questions and more with guests Fatima Pires, Madelaine Roos and Patrick Amis in the latest episode of #TheECBPodcast https://t.co/9M91nvkCjG https://t.co/c0YtEvQ1RR

Kerstin af Jochnick: Banks must improve their profitability, address IT and cyber risks as well as climate risks and use new technologies to combat money laundering. Read the full speech at https://t.co/zB50ComNc6

ECB Supervisory Board member Kerstin af Jochnick calls for completing the banking union by making the resolution framework more credible and harmonised and by implementing a European deposit insurance scheme.

ECB Supervisory Board member Kerstin af Jochnick says banks that have been quicker to adjust to the Basel standards are in a better position to support their customers. That’s why banks need to implement Basel III faithfully, consistently and in good time https://t.co/zB50ComNc6 https://t.co/ohUo1yOgD6

ECB Vice-President Luis de Guindos says completing the capital markets union requires improvements in two key areas: the dynamism of private equity investments, particularly in risk capital markets, as well as sustainable finance. Read more: https://t.co/n1JcuZndpD

Central banks need to have a solid understanding of the role of inflation expectations as well as of the side effects of unconventional monetary policy. This will be an important part of the ECB’s ongoing strategy review https://t.co/yj55RcDyW9
This trade-off is particularly stark in the vicinity of the effective lower bound. Attempting to shorten the horizon may increase risks to financial stability.
Such persistent supply shocks pose a dilemma for monetary policy. They call for a lengthening of the medium-term horizon but this may risk a destabilisation of inflation expectations.
She argues that two structural factors contribute to low inflation: the changed role of energy inflation and the cushioning effect of higher profit margins.
The ECB aims to reach its inflation aim over the medium term. The relevant horizon depends on the nature, size and persistence of economic shocks.
How long is the medium term? ECB Executive Board member @Isabel_Schnabel discusses this question in her speech today in London https://t.co/V7e7tIAovd https://t.co/ori4BbH42m
Speech Isabel Schnabel: How long is the medium term? Monetary policy in a low inflation environment https://t.co/r3WBsKRS0O

@COP26 @Lagarde Lagarde: The transition to a carbon-neutral economy provides opportunities, not just risks. By shifting the horizon away from the short term and contributing to a more sustainable economy, the financial sector can become a powerful force acting in our collective interest. (7/7)

@COP26 @Lagarde Lagarde: Substantial investment is likely to be required to underpin the energy transition, with some estimates running to hundreds of billions of euro each year in the EU alone. Meeting that challenge requires contributions from both the public and private sector. (6/7)

@COP26 @Lagarde Lagarde: Greater disclosure by companies on their climate exposure is a prerequisite, bolstering the ability of market participants and financial institutions to carry out appropriate risk assessment. (5/7)

@COP26 @Lagarde Lagarde: Early and coordinated action can help deliver a smooth transition to a carbon-neutral economy. But if intervention is delayed, the reduction in emissions may have to be sharper, resulting in a disorderly, disjointed and more disruptive transition for the economy. (4/7)

@COP26 @Lagarde Lagarde: Insurance and economic losses caused by climate-related events are likely to start trending upwards as a share of GDP. Banks, insurance and reinsurance companies need to consider the risks such events create. (3/7)
@COP26 @Lagarde Lagarde: Climate change constitutes a major challenge, causing both threats and opportunities that will significantly affect the economy and the financial sector. (2/7)
Speech Fabio Panetta: Protecting the European financial sector: the Cyber Information and Intelligence Sharing Initiative https://t.co/Hz30YDVBxB

As part of the #ECBstrategyreview, we want to hear from people living in the euro area. Share your thoughts and ideas with us using the #ECBListens Portal – we’re looking forward to hearing from you! https://t.co/DyqVQbGIZD https://t.co/LrkJqO92A8

Lane on fiscal policy: If fiscal policy were to play a more supportive role alongside monetary policy, it would alleviate the constraints on monetary policy. Read the full speech 8/8 https://t.co/XXHYnpWSVq

Lane on the macroeconomic effect: Our measures have made a considerable contribution to the euro area economy. A counterfactual exercise indicates that, in the absence of our unconventional measures, growth, employment and inflation would have been considerably lower. 7/8 https://t.co/Ej8essCrXa

Lane on asset purchases: We are confident that the effects of our asset purchases continue to feed through to euro area financial conditions. Our experience does not indicate that asset purchases entail diminishing returns over time. 6/8

Lane on targeted longer-term refinancing operations: Participating banks granted significantly more favourable rates to their corporate clients than non-participating banks. This suggests a sizeable easing of financing conditions for firms, especially in vulnerable countries. 5/8 https://t.co/8Dv99k26rb

Lane on bank profitability: Substantial differences in return on equity across different regions with broadly similar monetary conditions suggest that factors other than interest rates are more important in determining the overall profitability of the banking system. 4/8 https://t.co/SsT20lxaVf

Lane on negative rates: Evidence shows that the improving financing conditions stemming from negative interest rates are feeding their way into the real economy through increased bank loans. There is also evidence that negative rates have increased corporate investment. 3/8 https://t.co/QF6OLjXBL0

Lane on forward guidance: The available evidence suggests that the ECB’s rate forward guidance has been and continues to be an effective monetary policy tool and that the transmission of forward guidance to financial conditions and the economy has remained stable over time. 2/8

[THREAD] Chief Economist Philip R. Lane reflected on the ECB’s experience of non-standard monetary policy measures today in a speech at the 2020 US Monetary Policy Forum. Read the full speech 1/8 https://t.co/XXHYnpWSVq

Andrea Enria: Supervisors’ actions must also be transparent and their policies clear, predictable and comparable. There is room for clarifying our policies on mergers and acquisitions regarding the assessment process, capital requirements and the treatment of badwill.

Chair of ECB Supervisory Board Andrea Enria says more transparency on banks helps make markets more efficient and stable and underpins trust. Panetta: The case for European economic integration remains as strong as ever, if not stronger 2/4
